metadata./Title: Conjoined twin at abdomen: twin A anencephaly and face presentation with twin B cephalic presentation: a case report and review of the literature
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Abstract:
Abstract 
Objectives Conjoined twins are described as having been physically fused during pregnancy and delivery. They 
share some vital organs, such as the heart, lungs, liver, abdomen, etc. The article aims to present a unique
sections.Discussion:
discussion 
on conjoined twins at the abdomen, with twin A with anencephaly and face presentation and twin B with cephalic 
presentation. It is a conjoined twin fused at the abdomen. Twin A has anencephaly with lung and abdomen out side of the abdomen, with negative fetal heartbeat, and Twin B has cephalic presentation with a well-formed head 
and positive heartbeat. Conjoined twin is rarely diagnosed at delivery, but in resource-limited countries such as Ethio pia, it is diagnosed during delivery. It had a psychological impact both for pregnant women and the family. Therefore, 
appropriate counseling of pregnant women to have early ultrasound screening and follow-up is crucial.
Case summary We encountered a rare case of a conjoined twin pregnancy involving twin A with anencephaly 
and face presentation and twin B with cephalic presentation. The patient, a 19-year-old woman from rural Ethiopia, 
presented at Nekemte Specialized Hospital with pushing down pain and a gush of fluid per vagina for 10 hours. 
After admission, an obstetric ultrasound revealed a twin pregnancy with twin A presenting with anencephaly (face 
presentation) and a negative fetal heart rate, and twin B presenting with cephalic presentation and a positive fetal 
heart rate. The patient underwent a cesarean section, and the procedure resulted in one conjoined twin with anencephaly and the other well formed. After a week of recovery, the patient was discharged with counseling for future 
pregnancies.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Conjoined twinning is a rare phenomenon, occurring in 1 in 50,000–100,000. It is rarely diagnosed dur ing delivery. However, in resource-limited setups, it is diagnosed during delivery.
Keywords  Conjoined twins, Pregnancy
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Conjoined twins are defined by the conjoined (shared) 
body area, resulting from incomplete monozygotic twin ning. It is where the embryonic disc does not divide com pletely, or adjacent embryonic discs fuse. The earliest 
prenatal diagnosis enabling assessment for shared vital 
organs is desirable for optimal obstetric management of 
pregnancies. Sonographic diagnosis of conjoined twins 
has been reported, and has been diagnosed in the third *Correspondence:
Leta Hinkosa Dinsa
leta.hinko43@gmail.com
1 Department of Midwifery, School of Nursing and Midwifery, Wolegga 
University, Nekemte city, Oromia Regional State, Ethiopia
2 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Nekemte Specialized 
Hospital, Nekemte City, Oromia Regional State, Ethiopia
Page 2 of 4 Dinsa and Mengesha  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:597 
trimester, especially during delivery, where sonographic 
assessment is available. The incidence of conjoined twin ning is estimated to be 1 in 50,000 to 1 in 100,000 deliver ies [1–4].
Conjoined twins represent one of the rarest forms of 
congenital anomalies. The incidence appears remark ably similar throughout the world, although an incidence 
as high as 1 per 20,000 births has been reported from 
Atlanta. Approximately 40–60% of conjoined twins are 
stillborn and an additional 35% survive only 1 day [5–7].
Conjoined twins are rare occurrences in obstetric/
pediatric practice. More commonly known as Siamese 
twins, this phenomenon is shrouded in mystery and con sidered a curiosity by the public. Current technology is 
lending a helping hand in the early diagnosis of conjoined 
twins, with few cases of diagnosis during delivery time. 
Frequently, the twins are born dead, but in a few cases, 
the twins survive [8, 9].
Conjoined twins are infrequently encountered by 
obstetricians. Many of these pregnancies do not achieve 
a viable gestational age due to miscarriage or pregnancy 
termination, with exceptional cases arriving at term and 
being diagnosed during delivery. Much of the clinical care 
literature focuses on postnatal management from a neo natology and pediatric surgery perspective; guidance on 
obstetrical management of a conjoined twin pregnancy 
is limited. This case report aims to report the conjoined 
twin pregnancy at the abdomen with twin A with anen cephaly, face presentation, fetal heart beat (FHB) nega tive and lung and bowel outside of abdomen, and with 
twin B with cephalic presentation, fetal heart beat posi tive, and well-formed head with cephalic presentation 
that was diagnosed at term during delivery at Nekemte 
Specialized Hospital. Routine prenatal ultrasound should 
be there with the ability to detect virtually all conjoined 
twin gestations. For families faced with a conjoined twin 
diagnosis, obstetric counseling must explore the expect ant parents’ values while providing realistic and detailed 
expectations for postnatal care. Counseling should start 
as soon as the diagnosis of conjoined twins is made 
[10–14].
The importance of this research is to provide a report 
for a better comprehension of the various aspects related 
to conjoined twins. It gives healthcare providers an excel lent opportunity to reexamine, reevaluate, and counsel all 
pregnant women to have ultrasonographic examinations 
at an early time in pregnancy.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation
This is a 19-year-old gravida 1 mother from rural 
Ethiopia (Western Oromia, Wayu Tuqa Woreda), 
amenorrheic for 9 months. She presented to Nekemte 
Specialized Hospital with pushing down pain and gush of fluid per vagina for 10 hours. She had antenatal care 
follow-up at Wayu Tuqa Health Center two times and 
received TT1 and TT2 during her follow-up. Her blood 
type is RH B+  and urine analysis was nonrevealing 
(Table  1). However, she had no obstetrics ultrasound 
examination. She has no fever, headache, vaginal bleed ing, or epigastric pain. The patient has no history of 
medical problems such as diabetes mellitus, hyperten sion, or cardiac or renal problems.
On examination, she was acutely sick-looking. Her 
vital signs were blood pressure (BP) of 110/60 mmHg, 
pulse rate (PR) of 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate 
(RR) of 20 breaths per minute, and temperature 37.1 °C. 
She had pink conjunctivae. The lymph glandular sys tem, chest, and cardiovascular system were normal.
On abdominal examination, term-sized gravid uterus, 
with two uterine contractions in 10 minutes lasting 
30–35 seconds, FHB+  (133 beats per minute), inspec tion of external genitalia showed no vulvar mass or 
lesion. On genitourinary on digital vaginal cervix was 4 
cm, with face presentation. On the integumentary sys tem, she had no palmar pallor. On neurologic examina tion, she was oriented to time, person, and place. She 
had normal reflexes and no neurologic deficits.
She was admitted to Nekemte Specialized Hospital 
with a diagnosis of the active first stage of labor plus 
rupture of membrane plus face presentation, then after 
4 hours she was evaluated for cervical arrest, and an 
obstetrics ultrasound was done and she was diagnosed 
with twin pregnancies. Twin A had anencephaly (face 
presentation) FHB negative, and Twin B had cephalic 
presentation FHB positive. For cervical arrest second ary to poor uterine contraction in addition to twin 
pregnancy, she was prepared for CS after spinal anes thesia lower uterine segment tranisverse cesarean sec tion (LUST CS) was done. The outcome was conjoined 
twin at the abdomen, one with anencephaly with the 
Table 1 Laboratory investigation summary of 19-yearold patient with diagnosis of twin pregnancy; twin A with 
anencephaly (face presentation) fetal heartbeat (FHB) negative, 
and twin B cephalic presentation
RH Rhesus factors, VDRL Venereal Disease Research Laboratory, PICT Providerinitiated counselling and testing, HBSAG Hepatitis B Surface AntigenLaboratory test
sections.Results:
results
Parameters Results
Blood group and RH factors B positive
VDRL Negative
PICT Negative
HBSAG Negative
Urine analysis Nonrevealing
Page 3 of 4
 Dinsa and Mengesha  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:597 
 
lung and bowel outside and heartbeat negative, and the 
other with well-formed head and heartbeat positive in 
the first minute (Fig. 1 ).
Conclusion: Conjoined twinning is a rare phenomenon, 
occurring in 1 in 50,000–100,000. It is rarely diagnosed 
during delivery. However, in resource-limited setups, it is 
diagnosed during delivery.
Discussion
It is rare to diagnose conjoined twin pregnancy during 
delivery. It is a rare and complex anomaly of the new born. They require a highly experienced center equipped 
to diagnose in early pregnancy. Conjoined twins have 
been a source of fascination for both the public and the 
medical profession since time immemorial. Their birth 
is viewed as an ominous sign of impending disaster. 
The birth of conjoined twins is a difficult and dramatic 
moment for parents. It is also a difficult situation for the 
team of physicians, midwives, and other required hospi tal staff to carry out treatment and care of these specific 
developmental anomalies [8, 10].
Many anomalies associated with conjoined twins are 
lost in utero or in early postpartum period. If the pathol ogy can be diagnosed during the prenatal period, termi nation may be an option according to gestational age. In 
the absence of an intrauterine diagnosis, the situation is 
much more serious, and delivery can threaten the moth er’s life as well as the fetus’s life. Therefore, encouraging 
all pregnant people to have early ultrasound is crucial for 
safe pregnancy and delivery [15].
The early diagnosis of conjoined twins is important in 
the management of the situation and in reducing mater nal mortality through absenting evacuation, therapeutic 
abortus, and hysterotomy during the first trimester [13, 
16, 17].
Prenatal screening and diagnosis of conjoined twins is 
usually performed by ultrasonography to characterize the diagnosis of conjoined twins. Conjoined twins have a low 
survival rate, and the prognosis is generally poor. There fore, early antenatal diagnosis is important. The progno sis is mainly affected by specific fusion parts and related 
malformations. Due to the high incidence of complex 
heart defects, the survival rate of conjoined twins is the 
lowest. Therefore, neonatal morbidity and mortality rates 
may also increase. The risk of spontaneous loss of preg nancy also increased [17].
In our cases, the diagnosis was made during the third 
trimester at delivery time, which makes them very rare. 
As mentioned above, conjoined twins will most likely not 
arrive at term except in rare cases. This case report is 
not without limitations. The lack of ultrasound images is 
among its limitations.
Conclusions
Conjoined twin pregnancy is rarely diagnosed during 
third trimesters, especially during delivery. However, in 
resource-limited setups, it is diagnosed during delivery. 
Therefore, encouraging all pregnant women to have an 
early ultrasound examination is essential.
Abbreviations
AFSOL  Active first stage of labor
FHB  Fetal heartbeat
CS  Cesarean section
RR  Respiratory rate
PR  Pulse rate
Acknowledgements
We thank the patient for allowing the publication of this case report.

All authors made a significant contribution to the work reported; Leta Hinkosa

analysis, and interpretation, or all these areas; they took part in drafting, revising, or critically reviewing the article; Asfaw Mengesha gave final approval 
of the version to be published; and both authors have agreed on the journal 
to which the article has been submitted and agree to be accountable for all 
aspects of the work.

The datasets used and/or analyzed during the present study are available from

Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
Ethical clearance was obtained from the Research Ethics Review Commit tee of Wolegga University. The study protocol is performed per the relevant 
guidelines.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
